fields.content: A platform for accessing OSPC's open-source tax models.

Some random words here. Toggle the CPI control to indicate whether a parameter should be adjusted for inflation. Enter comma separated values into a field to indicate the multiple years of tax law. Similarly, do not use commas as thousands separators. You are looking at default parameters for 2015.
Distribution and Revenue Tables for Federal Individual Income Taxes

OSPC's TaxBrain allows users to assess how tax policy changes will affect the Federal government's budget and the distribution of the tax burden across income groups.

TaxBrain is currently in beta. Our most active areas of development include incorporating a macroeconomic model to produce dynamic revenue estimates that take into the impact of taxes on the economy, incorporating individual behavioral changes, and expanding the measure of income for our distributional tables. The source code for the underlying tax calculator is available on GitHub and we welcome reviewers and collaborators!

TaxBrain relies on a micro dataset that closely reproduces the multivariate distribution of income, deduction and credit items in 2008, extrapolated to 2015-2025 levels in accordance with CBO forecasts available in Spring 2015. It is intended to match similar but confidential data used by the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. Additional information on non-filers is taken from the March 2013 Current Population Survey.

While TaxBrain is in beta, there is NO GUARANTEE OF ACCURACY. THE RESULTS SHOULD NOT CURRENTLY BE USED FOR PUBLICATIONS, JOURNAL ARTICLES, OR RESEARCH PURPOSES.
All of our code is available on Github.com.
We document the economics, data, and software behind our models.
All of our code is freely available and we encourage peer review.
You can run our models yourself through our webapp interface or by downloading the code and using it with your own data.
We welcome anyone, whether you are a modeler, software developer, economist, or policy analyst, to help improve and expand our suite of models.
Over the coming months we will release TaxBrain to successively larger groups of beta testers. Sign up for our mailing list to learn more about the project.
A simulator to analyze the budgetary impact of taxes.
A LABORATORY FOR PREDICTING THE EFFECTS OF PUBLIC POLICY
The Open Source Policy Center is dedicated to encouraging good policy by making policy analysis more transparent, accessible, and collaborative.

Many desktop publishing packages and web page editors now use Lorem Ipsum as their default model text, and a search for 'lorem ipsum' will uncover many web sites still in their infancy. Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Richard McClintock, a Latin professor at Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia, looked up one of the more obscure Latin words, consectetur, from a Lorem Ipsum passage, and going through the cites of the word in classical literature, discovered the undoubtable source. Lorem Ipsum comes from sections 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 of "de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum" (The Extremes of Good and Evil) by Cicero, written in 45 BC. This book is a treatise on the theory of ethics, very popular during the Renaissance. The first line of Lorem Ipsum, "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet..", comes from a line in section 1.10.32.
